I will definitely order the chirashi next time I go there, and I plan to because the quality seemed quite good.
sashimi.author: H K.
sashimi.review: I came here for dinner this past Sunday night with a friend.  I ordered the sashimi combo, and she ordered the chirashi.  That way we can have a comparison between the two since those are items I usually like to order.  The sashimi set had 12 pieces consisting of three each of tuna, salmon, and yellowtail.  It was pretty standard.  The fish was quite fresh and delicious.  Her chirashi made me envious though because it was highlighted by a large shrimp with the head still there.  It looked like a large amaebi (the sweet shrimp), one of my favorite at some places.  The rest of the chirashi was nicely presented also.  I will definitely order the chirashi next time I go there, and I plan to because the quality seemed quite good.

excerpts: - I tried the chirashi don, a selection of sashimi spread on a bed of sushi rice.
The fish was nice and fresh, and the portions were ample.
Not exactly the most adventurous, however, with salmon, yellowtail, tuna, octopus, egg, and mackeral making up the sashimi.
There was also a nice, large spotted prawn joining the mix, which made for a nice presentation.

The sushi rice was also well cooked. 
-
Also tried the crunchy roll, which was spicy tuna covered in tempura crumbs and eel sauce with some more tuna on top.
The eel sauce really masks the flavor of anything else in this roll, so we couldn't really taste much of the tuna or spicy tuna.
Tempura
udon -
The broth was fairly light and the noodles were not too chewy.
Tempura was ok, as the shrimp tempura seemed a little overcooked and the tempura batter was somewhat dense.
They give a pretty good amount of it, though.
The udon also has cooked carrots in it.
$21 for the chirashi don, $4-5 for standard nigiri, $10-15 for big rolls, $14 for tempura udon (that's pricey).
Open until 10:30, so if I'm craving sushi, I'll definitely consider coming back to this place.
sashimi.author: Saunders C.
sashimi.review:
Boom. Review #200 for Fuji.

I really like little japanese restaurants like this. One of those places that sits in a sleepy little strip;  you might not notice it unless you were walking right by. But when you do venture through the door, you're surprised to find most seats filled with people happily eating their nigiri and slurping away at the udon. It's popular enough that they have their regulars who sit at the sushi bar on any given night talking to the sushi chefs. The place is very welcoming and spacious. The service was really friendly and attentive, they checked on us consistently and cleared the dishes right away. 

The menu offers a varied selection, while the fresh fish of the day are posted on the wall. They have a lot of different rolls, but one that caught my eye was the Banana Split. I love my bananas and all, but in a sushi roll? 

- I tried the chirashi don, a selection of sashimi spread on a bed of sushi rice. The fish was nice and fresh, and the portions were ample. Not exactly the most adventurous, however, with salmon, yellowtail, tuna, octopus, egg, and mackeral making up the sashimi. There was also a nice, large spotted prawn joining the mix, which made for a nice presentation. The sushi rice was also well cooked. 
- Also tried the crunchy roll, which was spicy tuna covered in tempura crumbs and eel sauce with some more tuna on top. The eel sauce really masks the flavor of anything else in this roll, so we couldn't really taste much of the tuna or spicy tuna. 
- Tempura udon - The broth was fairly light and the noodles were not too chewy. Tempura was ok, as the shrimp tempura seemed a little overcooked and the tempura batter was somewhat dense. They give a pretty good amount of it, though. The udon also has cooked carrots in it. I've heard that's a Korean influence, but I'm not sure. 

Pricewise, I'd say it's slightly above what you would expect to pay at a casual sushi restaurant. $21 for the chirashi don, $4-5 for standard nigiri, $10-15 for big rolls, $14 for tempura udon (that's pricey). Open until 10:30, so if I'm craving sushi, I'll definitely consider coming back to this place.

excerpts: Other than that, the sushi and sashimi is pretty fresh too!
Too bad they are kind of in the expensive side of my budget.
sashimi.author: Miss C.
sashimi.review:
I always order Finding Nemo here! Amazing, amazing roll! I don't usually love spicy tuna, but this over here, is an exception! Then I love the Lion King roll! My friend from Seattle asked me to bring her one Lion King roll when I visited her. Yep, that's how much she loves it. and she lives in Seattle! LOL. 
Other than that, the sushi and sashimi is pretty fresh too! Too bad they are kind of in the expensive side of my budget.

excerpts: From the salmon sashimi and spicy tuna, to even the uni, it is all fresh.
Their tempura is hot, and not too greasy.
And their teriyaki chicken is superb.
sashimi.author: Brian L.
sashimi.review:
Either yelpers these days don't know what good food is, or they are just lying through their teeth. 

I've been coming to Fuji for years, with both family and friends. And I must say I have yet to be disappointed. I feel bad for those who had a bad experience here because quite frankly I never had. 

The service, to my taste, is what good normal service should be. The staff are nice, friendly and attentive. Nothing bad, nothing over the top special. Though it can get slow during the busy hours but c'mon what restaurant won't be bogged down by a slew of hungry customers? 

The food is always delicious. The sushi is always fresh. From the salmon sashimi and spicy tuna, to even the uni, it is all fresh. Their tempura is hot, and not too greasy. And their teriyaki chicken is superb. Unlike some other restaurants that serve distasteful burned chicken drenched in teriyaki sauce, Fuji's is light and not overpowering.

It is run by koreans, but who cares, cause the food is good. Its hard to find a decent, consistent Japanese restaurant anyway. Fuji is my go to place for Japanese. Yes, it may be a bit pricy but hey, it is the west portal area, rent is high. For those of you who have had a bad day here, I urge you to try it again. To the new folks, when you get a chance, come out here and try it. I hope you won't be disappointed.

~ Fuji is delicate.

excerpts: They have absolutely the freshest sashimi I've ever tasted.
I ordered the assorted sashimi plate and it was DIVINE.
Buttery and fatty salmon, tuna, and hamachi.
sashimi.author: Marissa N.
sashimi.review:
First off, half off all sake and beer on THURSDAYS!!!  That was a pleasant surprise when I went there =)

They have absolutely the freshest sashimi I've ever tasted.  I ordered the assorted sashimi plate and it was DIVINE.  Buttery and fatty salmon, tuna, and hamachi.  A-MAZ-ING.

The party I was with also ordered shrimp tempura (nice and crispy!), beef sukjyaki, a mango roll, AAANNND a large bottle of sake called Otokayama (16% alcohol people!  and tasty!).  It was a heavenly meal.  

I love going here b/c it's a neighborhood place that isn't super crowded in the early afternoon.  The service there is fine, and the sunshine always makes its way through the big windows.  This place is good for dates without making things too fancy, and there's always amazing fresh sushi.

excerpts: Luckily, I have recently been there for dinner many times and their chirashi sushi (sashimi sushi served arranged over sushi rice) has not been problematic at all.
sashimi.author: Diana Y.
sashimi.review:
If I had written this review a year ago, I would have given it five stars without any hesitation. I have frequented this restaurant since it first opened years ago, almost weekly for lunch. Unfortunately, the chef that used to run the place left a few months ago, and an unfortunate but subsequent downgrading of their food has happened.

It may be that I am a very picky person, or it may be that Fuji used to be an excellent, excellent place which raised my standards, but there was a period of time when their nigiri did not taste fresh, which is very distasteful to me, especially when it comes to raw fish. I could not finish my meal, and I almost decided to never go back. Only its lasting legacy from the past brought me back again.

Luckily, I have recently been there for dinner many times and their chirashi sushi (sashimi sushi served arranged over sushi rice) has not been problematic at all. So it appears that whatever issue it was with their raw fish has been resolved.

I also really like their salad dressing, which is not the cream kind that is often served in sushi restaurants, but rather a light, house-made vinegarette. 

Service has always been superb, and, while dinner can be expensive, the restaurant's lunch specials are very affordable, and quite moderately priced. The place is also well-kept and neat.

My only current complaint is that Fuji used to serve the best beef teriyaki in town. It was not over-cooked, or too tough. Since the change of chefs, I have been hard-pressed to find something comparable. 

Although Fuji has lost its flare that made it exceptional for me, I would still go there just because it is still an average to good sushi restaurant with good service and tasteful food in general. However, if I ever figure out where that chef went, I will take all my business there.

excerpts: The items that stood out most for me were the unagi (warm and tender), sashimi (loved the salmon) and a specialty roll that was not on the regular menu.
sashimi.author: Art D.
sashimi.review:
On my first visit here we rolled 11 deep and the staff took care of us with no problems whatsoever! They even hooked us up with a few complimentary large beers (we dropped some serious coin for dinner), which was unexpected and a nice touch...

We ordered all kinds of food and drinks (alcoholic and non-alcoholic) and nothing was forgotten...of course, the staff had nothing to do with the instance when one of my friends' orders was eaten by another friend, but that's another story... :-)

They seated us in the upstairs room and went to the trouble to set up and aim three fans at our table, just in case we were getting too hot battling over the tasty pieces of sushi that were being delivered to our table.

The items that stood out most for me were the unagi (warm and tender), sashimi (loved the salmon) and a specialty roll that was not on the regular menu. The spicy tuna I ordered was also tasty...

Overall the staff was very friendly and accommodating, the food was great and the prices were fair. Definitely a place that I'll get back to, especially since it's close to my 'hood!

excerpts:
but the rolls were one of the sloppiest...again...miuscule.....while the 4 pieces of seasoned tuna tartar over tempura fried leaf was creative...the taste came mostly from the thick heavy saucing of teriyaki and 1000 island type mixture...not impressed

for service...the waitresses.....so sweet and nice....soft spoken.....i feel bad even asking for water......interior is decently clean for a sushi joint in this aged building......

sashimi and rolls lunch for two with drinks and nice buzz?....$60......
sashimi.author: Hen A.
sashimi.review:
fish appeared fresh....bit icy cold...but decent....."large hot sake..please~!".....the minuscule portions wasn't going to do justice fillin' this hungry tummy.....drink the hunger away~!.....the "special" rolls were....well....sorry...but the rolls were one of the sloppiest...again...miuscule.....while the 4 pieces of seasoned tuna tartar over tempura fried leaf was creative...the taste came mostly from the thick heavy saucing of teriyaki and 1000 island type mixture...not impressed

for service...the waitresses.....so sweet and nice....soft spoken.....i feel bad even asking for water......interior is decently clean for a sushi joint in this aged building......

sashimi and rolls lunch for two with drinks and nice buzz?....$60......

excerpts: It's a big bowl of steaming hot sushi rice with fresh sashimi, apple slices, green onions, and watercress to garnish.
It also comes with a spicy red sauce so you can mix it all together
(Think Bi Bim Bop).
Remember to ask for minced garlic and jalapenos on the side.
They won't bring it to you unless you ask for it!
I know the ingredients sounds odd and you might think that the added jalapenos in addition to the spicy sauce would burn your booty-hole..
But it is well worth the sensation!
The torro (fatty tuna) sashimi is also one of the best I've tried..
It melts like buttah!
sashimi.author: H To The W.
sashimi.review:
As the cute little Leprechaun on the Food Network (30 Minute Meals) would say for the food here..and I quote "Yumm..OH".  

The food here is fantabulous.. Especially the Korean Chirashi!! It's a big bowl of steaming hot sushi rice with fresh sashimi, apple slices, green onions, and watercress to garnish. It also comes with a spicy red sauce so you can mix it all together (Think Bi Bim Bop). Remember to ask for minced garlic and jalapenos on the side. They won't bring it to you unless you ask for it! I know the ingredients sounds odd and you might think that the added jalapenos in addition to the spicy sauce would burn your booty-hole.. But it is well worth the sensation! (Ya know, if it does burn)

But you're taking it from a girl who packs a bottle of hot sauce in her purse, everywhere she goes.. 
Now what's in the flask is another story.

The torro (fatty tuna) sashimi is also one of the best I've tried.. It melts like buttah!

excerpts: Even their non-sushi/sashimi items are good, like their udon, tempura, gyoza and edamame.
Service is pretty good too.
Really not too much to complain about except maybe when we sit upstairs and the service is a tad bit slower.
But then again, if you're in a rush, just insist on a downstairs table.
Oh, just thought of one bad point.
The tables along the wall on the main floor can feel cramped if you have more than one person sitting on either side of the table.
Especially cramped if you're really sensitive about having your personal space.
sashimi.author: spiff e.
sashimi.review:
Freshest, best, most creative sushi in the area.  We go here just about every Sunday for dinner.  Dinosaur foot and Godzilla roll are two specials that you shouldn't miss (plus they're fun to say).  Even their non-sushi/sashimi items are good, like their udon, tempura, gyoza and edamame.  Service is pretty good too.  Really not too much to complain about except maybe when we sit upstairs and the service is a tad bit slower.  But then again, if you're in a rush, just insist on a downstairs table.

Oh, just thought of one bad point.  The tables along the wall on the main floor can feel cramped if you have more than one person sitting on either side of the table.  Especially cramped if you're really sensitive about having your personal space.

excerpts: I ordered the salmon sashimi dinner plate.
It came with miso soup and a bowl of salad, as well as a bowl of rice.
I was starving
so I thought it was good.
It was a bit on the pricey side, and I've had better salmon sashimi, but it was better than what I was expecting.
sashimi.author: Martin L.
sashimi.review:
I came here with a couple of buddies since we just wanted to walk down from his house to West Portal for dinner. We didn't really find anything we liked, so we just kept walking until we reached Fuji.

It's  pretty small place. The food was decent. I ordered the salmon sashimi dinner plate. It came with miso soup and a bowl of salad, as well as a bowl of rice. I was starving so I thought it was good. It was a bit on the pricey side, and I've had better salmon sashimi, but it was better than what I was expecting.

excerpts: we had sake sashimi, looking for mango roll, red dragon roll, and i believe the finding nemo roll.
they were all good, and generously sized rolls.
we also had a couple of large hot sakes and asahis...aside from my sashimi fix, this is primarily what i came here for...especially after a rare hectic work day =
sashimi.author: Ian Q.
sashimi.review:
what can i say about fuji?  obviously, with four stars, i liked it.  it's a small restaurant nestled on a street corner in west portal.  although small, it wasn't cramped...very cozy and welcoming.  the wait staff are attentive, yet far from overwhelming.  we had dinner here on a thursday night, and took advantage of 1/2 off sake & beer!

the food:  we had sake sashimi, looking for mango roll, red dragon roll, and i believe the finding nemo roll.  they were all good, and generously sized rolls.  we also had a couple of large hot sakes and asahis...aside from my sashimi fix, this is primarily what i came here for...especially after a rare hectic work day =P

upon closing time, we left as full, buzzed and happy patrons =)

excerpts: The hamachi sashimi was very nice.
sashimi.author: Mason W.
sashimi.review:
It had been a couple years since I had been to Fuji, back when I got  good sized groups of sushi fans to eat there on a few occasions.  Earlier tonight, my wife and I waited just a few minutes for perfect seats at the center of the sushi bar, right in front of the head sushi chef.  For a Friday night, the place was understandably busy.  We could see most of the other food going to other customers were a variety of maki rolls and other entrees.  Our interest was pure and simple:  nigiri, and lots of it!

The meal was surprisingly sublime.  The fish was cool, tender, fresh, and properly seasoned as appropriate, while the rice was perfectly room temperature, with the right balance of chewiness, smoothness, and subtle vinegar flavor.  We believe we were at an advantage with our close proximity to the head sushi chef.  The time from him making the nigiri to it entering our mouths could literally be measured in seconds.

Our favorites were the anago, the bonito, and the escolar, all bursting with flavor and wonderful mouth feel.  They were so good, we doubled up on those orders.  

Also good were the hotate, the kampachi, and the toro.  Less impressive, but still good, was the saba.  The hamachi sashimi was very nice.  The sunomono was good as well - I enjoyed the fresh piece of taco (octopus) from it.

The chef did comp us a special piece of toro with a nori wrap, no rice, and some sort of light color salty sauce.  That was quite nice of him.

For comparison, my wife and I commented to each other that this nigiri meal easily beat recent similar meals at Kabuto and Nagano on Geary St., and Higuma in Redwood City.  While not cheap, it was well worth the cost.

Perhaps our experience would not have been as good if we had not sat at the sushi bar, nor focused on nigiri, but since we thoroughly enjoyed this one meal, and I've had good experiences before at Fuji, I'm assigning a 5 star rating.  Choose wisely at this place for a great meal.

excerpts: tuna and salmon sashimi was really nice
, tempura was really crisp on the outside.
Service was good.
Will definitely be coming here again.
Next time we'll try more sushi.
Only downside...
we had to listen to Mariah Carey's Xmas album three times in a row before someone changed the CD.
sashimi.author: Miriam G.
sashimi.review: Started with the spicy tuna roll.  So fresh, and so spicy!  Then we had dinner boxes, which came with salad (really good vinaigrette with sunflower seeds) and miso soup.  Chicken teriyaki was so tender, and the salmon teriyaki wasn't over-cooked. tuna and salmon sashimi was really nice, tempura was really crisp on the outside.  Service was good. Will definitely be coming here again. Next time we'll try more sushi.  Only downside...we had to listen to Mariah Carey's Xmas album three times in a row before someone changed the CD.

excerpts: They offer delicious sashimi and nigiri that is extremely fresh and a great cut of fish.
Their rolls are inventive and have awesome flavor.
sashimi.author: Rebecca D.
sashimi.review: I scream sushi, you scream sushi, we all scream sushi. And going to Fuji makes you scream for more. They offer delicious sashimi and nigiri that is extremely fresh and a great cut of fish. Their rolls are inventive and have awesome flavor. Their Red & White Roll, Double Albacore Roll, and Scallop Roll are some of the standouts. Don't miss the gyoza, yakitori and shrimp tempura appetizers. Fuji's a great find in West Portal. Also they have a mezzanine level where you can have a huge group if you'd like.

excerpts: My brother's first complaint was that the sashimi salad he'd ordered was supposed have 8 pieces of maguro-
he got 5 and the waitress told him that's how the dish is NOW-
not like it is in the menu.
Hmmm.
Have had better pre-made sushi at Paradise Market in Marin.
DO NOT order any roe nigiri, unless you want to get sick eating old, pre-packed, unfresh fish eggs.
GAMIEST Aji (Spanish Mackeral)
I've ever had-
and it was on the fresh/special list.
Yikes!
Wild salmom nigiri was not that fresh or tasty either.
Hamachi was decent-
but do you need a HUGE piece of fish laying over a tiny ball of rice??
I don't mean to complain, but the presentation is off from the get go when this happens, right?
Too bad.
Nice staff, good location, fairly brisk service.
Pretty bad sushi.
sashimi.author: Sean E.
sashimi.review:
Don't think the owner/manager knows what he's doing here. And he stands there at the end of the sushi bar watching/staring at everyone. It's kind of uncomfortable, like he's making sure you like it/ don't have complaints.
Well, I have one. Try using FRESH fish in a Japanese sushi restaurant, cheapo! I mean c'mon, who are you trying to fool? No wonder the place is half empty on a Friday night. My brother's first complaint was that the sashimi salad he'd ordered was supposed have 8 pieces of maguro- he got 5 and the waitress told him that's how the dish is NOW- not like it is in the menu. Hmmm.
Have had better pre-made sushi at Paradise Market in Marin. DO NOT order any roe nigiri, unless you want to get sick eating old, pre-packed, unfresh fish eggs. GAMIEST Aji (Spanish Mackeral) I've ever had- and it was on the fresh/special list. Yikes! Wild salmom nigiri was not that fresh or tasty either. Hamachi was decent- but do you need a HUGE piece of fish laying over a tiny ball of rice?? I don't mean to complain, but the presentation is off from the get go when this happens, right?
Too bad. Nice staff, good location, fairly brisk service. Pretty bad sushi.

excerpts: Really fresh sashimi!
Tried this place for first time last night.
Was really impressed with the amazingly fresh yellowtail sashimi and the magura tuna was good too.
Didn't care for the california roll--although made with fresh crab, it was dry...and the yakitori chicken was on the dry side too.
Will definitely go back for the sashimis.
sashimi.author: Kailee Q.
sashimi.review: Really fresh sashimi!  Tried this place for first time last night.  Was really impressed with the amazingly fresh yellowtail sashimi and the magura tuna was good too.  Didn't care for the california roll--although made with fresh crab, it was dry...and the yakitori chicken was on the dry side too.  Will definitely go back for the sashimis.

excerpts: I always order sashimi dinner combination.
sashimi.author: Sweet J.
sashimi.review:
I love this place. I always order sashimi dinner combination. It comes with miso soup, salad, and rice.

The fish is fresh. We've tried other sushi places, but we always come back to Fuji.

Try Stuff Mushroom. It's super yummy!!!

excerpts: When we left, there was still shiro maguro sashimi left on my plate, and not because I was full.
This experience (shiro maguro sashimi dinner, maguro sashimi, one roll for her(second was canceled) set me back $50.)
This experience (shiro maguro sashimi dinner, maguro sashimi, one roll for her(second was canceled) set me back $50.)
sashimi.author: John K.
sashimi.review:
Hmm lessee...what was the phrase from the girlfriend again?  Oh yes...

"That place was so disgusting I wouldn't feed it to our dog!  Who puts mustard on sushi?"

She ordered two rolls, I've been on a shashimi kick so I ordered that.  I'm 75% done with my very mediocre fish (had to ask myself "OK what day is it...should they have gotten a fresh delivery recently or are they coming off a weekend? Nope, they really should have fish fresher than what I get at the j-town supermarket") and she's still sitting there looking at her tea.  Finally I grumble at the wait staff, they wander off to look at what they had written on the bill - did you completely forget the order you took already?  There were 4 other tables left, the bar was mostly quiet.  I know, this is what I get for sitting at a table and not at the bar.

I too used to come to this place a few years ago(call it 2000 or so) and it was much better then.  I think it's turned into a place funded by the geriatrics who wander down out of St. Francis Wood, not knowing any better.

When we left, there was still shiro maguro sashimi left on my plate, and not because I was full.  This experience (shiro maguro sashimi dinner, maguro sashimi, one roll for her(second was canceled) set me back $50.)  I guess I helped fund their existence a little, too.

They get two stars only because I love raw fish, and I didn't get sick.  

Oh and PS, the dog did eat the roll.

excerpts:
japanese cuisine (to me) is supposed to be modest, simple and reflect the purity of the food item that you are about to consume (sashimi, broiled mackeral, etc.) 

however, with the explosion of westernized influences on japanese cuisine, rolls are extremely popular in the US.
sashimi.author: Lucy W.
sashimi.review:
i don't believe that rolls are a true representation of what japanese cuisine has to offer.  japanese cuisine (to me) is supposed to be modest, simple and reflect the purity of the food item that you are about to consume (sashimi, broiled mackeral, etc.) 

however, with the explosion of westernized influences on japanese cuisine, rolls are extremely popular in the US.  and to me, if it's made right, it can be a fantastic explosion of flavors and textures that our palatte can take on at once.

i believe that of all the west portal sushi establishments, this place does it right.  on a thursday nght, all of the tables were packed.  service can be a bit slow, but i barely noticed it since i was partaking in their thursday night special of 1/2 off sake and beer (and i'm a big sucker for discounted drinks).

the liger roll came and it was extremely well presented.  the honey and wasabi mayo combo on plate is such a fabulous contrast!  the portions were filling and the fish was fresh.  the saba donburi is pretty on point as well.  they serve the mackeral on a huge white platter, and while you may think that it's odd to serve it on a huge plate, i appreciated it because it allowed the mackeral to stand on it's own and shine, rather than drown in a sea of red in the typical bento boxes.

a bit expensive for sushi, but it's a welcome and comforting change from the party-filled atmosphere at other establishments in the neighborhood.  great place to go if you've got kids or want to have a conversation with someone without yelling at the top of your lungs.  and remember, you can't drink if you damage your vocal cords!

excerpts: In fact, my toro sashimi was still frozen when served to us.
sashimi.author: Richard K.
sashimi.review:
I used to "like" Fuji....When I say "like", I mean it was o.k., not great, but passable.  I'd go there when I was in the mood for suhsi, but not in the mood for driving.  My latest visit made me realize that bad sushi is alot more painful than driving any day of the week.

I didn't get sick or anything, but the sushi was unremarkable.  In fact, my toro sashimi was still frozen when served to us.  The escolar was pretty tasty, but the way they cut it made it look pretty unappetizing.   I don't think I'll be coming back here for a while.

excerpts: So I felt like I was eating sashimi more than sushi, but it was still good.
The service is good too.
I would eat here again.
sashimi.author: Emy s.
sashimi.review: This place is always playing J-pop to keep the Japanese-ness, which I like. The quality of the fish is good, but the fish:rice ratio is too much fish and too little rice. So I felt like I was eating sashimi more than sushi, but it was still good. The service is good too. I would eat here again.

excerpts: we ordered a bunch of the special rolls, sashimi and sake bombs.
My friends are really into sashimi and thought the rainbow trout was 'to die for.'
sashimi.author: elissa w.
sashimi.review:
yum yum. we ordered a bunch of the special rolls, sashimi and sake bombs. not sure if the rolls were amazing because I was drunk or it really was delicious.

The liger roll is great if you like saucy rolls. Also a big fan of the dragon foot roll. My friends are really into sashimi and thought the rainbow trout was 'to die for.' we also got some raw oysters which were pretty good.

this place was good, we also managed to rack up a $200 bill between 4 people.

excerpts: their sashimi on the other hand is nothing spectacular.
sashimi.author: Helen L.
sashimi.review: fuji's sushi is pretty expensive but their cooked sushi is yummy. their sashimi on the other hand is nothing spectacular. i had the chirashi and it was small and just ok. again not as great as the place in fremont. if i were to go back again for a third time it would be just for their cooked sushi.

excerpts: Honestly, any place that gives me a nice size cut of hamachi sashimi will win me over.
sashimi.author: David O.
sashimi.review: Place was pretty good.  Honestly, any place that gives me a nice size cut of hamachi sashimi will win me over.

excerpts: that changed when I took a risk and ate some sashimi here.
I seriously craved it all week and went back twice within the next two weeks.
The service is good not great
sashimi.author: Chelsey L.
sashimi.review:
Great sushi! Im always scared to eat actual raw sushi but that changed when I took a risk and ate some sashimi here.  I seriously craved it all week and went back twice within the next two weeks.  The service is good not great but everyone is really nice.

The sushi is fresh and delicious!!! great non raw sushi as well but everything is just delicious and will definitely leave you satisfied!!!

if you arent one for raw sushi defintely try the lion king rolls and the firecracker rolls!!!

Go try this place you wont be dissapointed!

excerpts: The double albacore roll is my favorite roll, but I usually order sashimi and nigiri.
yum!
sashimi.author: Claudia M.
sashimi.review: I love this place! Great sushi, hardly ever a wait for a table and great service. It also has none of the pretensions of the hipper places and I think it is just as good. The double albacore roll is my favorite roll, but I usually order sashimi and nigiri. yum!

excerpts: I love sashimi and skim on sushi to cut down on my white rice intake and find Fuji to be reliable.
The menu is basic, extensive, and a bit pricey (new menu, new wait staff), but the food is fresh and delicious.
I'm shortening the rating to four stars because the current wait staff discouraged me from ordering sashimi a la carte and steered me toward the sashimi appetizer--and no substitutions.
Perhaps this was a new waiter.
Service may seem unfriendly to some
but they turn over tables as quickly as they can.
sashimi.author: M.D. L.
sashimi.review: This is a lovely neighborhood Japanese restaurant.  I love sashimi and skim on sushi to cut down on my white rice intake and find Fuji to be reliable.  The menu is basic, extensive, and a bit pricey (new menu, new wait staff), but the food is fresh and delicious.  I'm shortening the rating to four stars because the current wait staff discouraged me from ordering sashimi a la carte and steered me toward the sashimi appetizer--and no substitutions.  Perhaps this was a new waiter.  Service may seem unfriendly to some but they turn over tables as quickly as they can.

excerpts: Well, wife and I have eaten here a few times when we're craving sashimi and want something quick.
Needless to say, it's been decent most of the time.
The service is actually pretty bad.
Yesterday, my in-laws, along with my wife and our 9 month old, went for dinner and sat upstairs since the bottom was pretty full.
When the bill came, they had the nerves to already include 18% gratuity.
I asked the lady why this was included and she stated that it's standard practice for parties of 5 or more.
I told her that our infant doesn't count and that it's BS.
I concluded that the only reason she did this was because she had to walk up and down the flight of stairs to bring us our food.
I've gone numerous times with another couple who have a infant as well and we were never charged this.
Needless to say, I told them to leave it on the bill.
I guess they'd rather have a few dollars in their pockets now instead of a steady stream from a returning customer.
Don't get me wrong, I would of tipped them generously, it's the principle of the matter.
sashimi.author: diewney n.
sashimi.review:
Well, wife and I have eaten here a few times when we're craving sashimi and want something quick. Needless to say, it's been decent most of the time.
The service is actually pretty bad. Yesterday, my in-laws, along with my wife and our 9 month old, went for dinner and sat upstairs since the bottom was pretty full.
When the bill came, they had the nerves to already include 18% gratuity. I asked the lady why this was included and she stated that it's standard practice for parties of 5 or more. I told her that our infant doesn't count and that it's BS. I concluded that the only reason she did this was because she had to walk up and down the flight of stairs to bring us our food. I've gone numerous times with another couple who have a infant as well and we were never charged this.
Needless to say, I told them to leave it on the bill. I guess they'd rather have a few dollars in their pockets now instead of a steady stream from a returning customer. Don't get me wrong, I would of tipped them generously, it's the principle of the matter.
Oh well, back to EBISU!

Cheers

excerpts: We had the Beef Tataki for the appetizer, Godzilla roll, dinosaur foot
and I asked for the tuna roll because I was afraid I wouldn't like the giant rolls.
Each dish came out really fast and tasted fresh.
The sushi had just the right amount of sauce and wasn't over done with lots of junk on it.
We finished our meal with fried bananas with mango and green tea ice cream.
I finally found a sushi place where I can enjoy the fancy creations, too bad it is in San Francisco
and I live in Southern California.
beef tataki.author: Vicki G.
beef tataki.review: I am not the biggest fan of fancy sushi rolls but this place turned out to be the exception for me.  One of my friends is a regular here so she knew exactly what to order. We had the Beef Tataki for the appetizer, Godzilla roll, dinosaur foot and I asked for the tuna roll because I was afraid I wouldn't like the giant rolls. Each dish came out really fast and tasted fresh. The sushi had just the right amount of sauce and wasn't over done with lots of junk on it. We finished our meal with fried bananas with mango and green tea ice cream. I finally found a sushi place where I can enjoy the fancy creations, too bad it is in San Francisco and I live in Southern California.

excerpts: We ordered the chicken and the katsu donburi and both were very basic, yet terrible.
The katsu was wet and chewy, not crispy like usual, and the chicken was pretty bland.
The rice was very mushy as well.
Nowhere near worth the high price.
Ugh.
katsu donburi.author: David T.
katsu donburi.review: Pricey, yet so disappointing. We ordered the chicken and the katsu donburi and both were very basic, yet terrible.  The katsu was wet and chewy, not crispy like usual, and the chicken was pretty bland.  The rice was very mushy as well. Nowhere near worth the high price. Ugh.

excerpts: KATSU DONBURI DEEP FRIED PORK CUTLET
katsu donburi.author: William B.
katsu donburi.review:
Its been a while since I have not eaten at Japanese restaurant since the very last time I ate at Kamakura.. I have decided to explore another Japanese Restauraant this time I went to go try Fuji for lunch and had myself these items which I have eaten at Fuji during the lunch time hour...


KATSU DONBURI DEEP FRIED PORK CUTLET IN KATSU SAUCE W/ EGG

CALIFORNIA ROLL W/ REAL CRAB, AVOCADO AND CUCUMBER 5 PIECES AND ALSO COMES WITH MISO SOUP 

I ALSO WANTED TO TRY ASAHI BEER IN WHICH I DID IT TASTED GREAT

AFTER ALL NOW THAT I HAVE EATEN AT FUJI FOR THE FIRST TIME THE LUNCH MEAL THAT I HAVE EATEN WASNT THAT BAD AT ALL!!!

excerpts: My sister ordered the Oyako Donburi (Chicken/Egg over rice).
The Bento was decent, but definitely nothing special at all.
California Rolls were a good size, but were prepared very sloppy.
I guess the sushi chef didn't get a good grip on the bamboo wrap, to where the rice wasn't tightly put together.
oyako donburi.author: Cass J.
oyako donburi.review:
Nothing special or memorable... just simple and expensive.  Upon walking into Fuji for lunch today, we were greeted by our Korean waitress Young Jin, quickly seated.  We were somewhat confused about the attitude of the restaurant as there was Mexican music playing.  But what they hey, we were hungry, and didn't want go to far for lunch.  As more folks walked in for lunch, the music quickly changed to Japanese music.  

Prices for lunch weren't insanely unreasonable, but for the quality it definitely wasn't worth it.  We ordered the Vegetable Tempura appetizer which was alright--the batter became quite soggy very fast. But we were hungry, so we didn't take long to kill the plate.  

I ordered the Bento Box of California Roll and Chicken Teriyaki.  Bento's came with miso.  My sister ordered the Oyako Donburi (Chicken/Egg over rice).  The Bento was decent, but definitely nothing special at all.   California Rolls were a good size, but were prepared very sloppy. I guess the sushi chef didn't get a good grip on the bamboo wrap, to where the rice wasn't tightly put together.  Needless to say, the rice came apart very easy.  

The Oyako Don, was lacking in flavor and very bland, Angie had to pour the remaining Tempura sauce over her rice, and even that didn't help much.  

We also ordered the Lion King Roll, which was a California Roll with cooked Salmon on top.  Eh...it was just as sloppily made with the rice falling off on certain parts.  

Overall, the food wasn't terrible, I actually really liked the California Roll and Tempura, but it definitely wasn't anything that made me say "Wow!"

$45.00 with tip...

excerpts: My partner got the fish katsu, and it tasted as if they had trusted the Gorton's fisherman a little too much.
Salad was iceberg lettuce and it also came with miso and rice.
fish katsu.author: Michael G.
fish katsu.review:
Went to Fuji for their lunch special. Wanted to order the Tekka Maki + 5 nigiri but one of them was shrimp and I am allergic. Requested a substitution with something non-shellfish, probably cheaper for them than the shrimp, but the only way they were willing to do this was to charge me extra (the waiter didn't know how much, and didn't even know how much the special originally was). 

My partner got the fish katsu, and it tasted as if they had trusted the Gorton's fisherman a little too much. Salad was iceberg lettuce and it also came with miso and rice. All this for $10. 

We agree with other reviewers that Taraval Okazu Ya has better quality, service, and value.

excerpts: I ordered the chicken katsu curry, but either I forgot to include "curry" or the waiter misheard and my food ended up coming out separately.
They were able to add curry as a side to my giant plate of katsu, though.
It contained a lot of potatoes and carrots, which I appreciated; however, the curry itself was too thick.
I like thick curry, but this was more like congealed liquid.
It was barely fluid and was honestly kind of gross for me to look at.
The breading on my katsu did not stay on the chicken itself, so maybe if they used different binding material, it would've been better.
Portions were huge though
chicken katsu curry.author: Leslie C.
chicken katsu curry.review:
I've been here once before, several years ago and can vaguely recall that the sushi was OK. I came back tonight with a friend when they opened (they surprisingly got pretty busy!). 

We ordered the takoyaki to share, which I really enjoyed. I think it came with about 7 balls and more than enough bonito flakes, which I really appreciated. My friend ordered udon with tempura, which seemed to be packed with vegetables! It was a huge bowl. I ordered the chicken katsu curry, but either I forgot to include "curry" or the waiter misheard and my food ended up coming out separately. They were able to add curry as a side to my giant plate of katsu, though. It contained a lot of potatoes and carrots, which I appreciated; however, the curry itself was too thick. I like thick curry, but this was more like congealed liquid. It was barely fluid and was honestly kind of gross for me to look at. The breading on my katsu did not stay on the chicken itself, so maybe if they used different binding material, it would've been better. Portions were huge though and I had more than enough to take home for a second meal. 

The two servers were really nice, so that made up for the not so pleasant curry. Kind of. Would I return? Not likely, but then again, I felt the same way after my first experience.

excerpts: The chicken katsu curry I had was cooked right, the coating coming off a bit but not too much in the sauce, the vegetables in the curry in the right proportion, and fukujin-zuke!
I never expected it would be so hard to find properly made and served Japanese curry in Northern California, but it is hard to find--look no longer, it's made right at Fuji.
The Finding Nemo was the sort of roll we'd seldom see in Japan, but that's OK--it was made well and tasted great.
It was similar to the Rainbow Roll we get at Sushi to Dai For in San Rafael, but with spicy maguro in the middle.
My wife and son also greatly enjoyed their combo bentos.
They are at least as hard to please as me, but the consensus was five stars!
chicken katsu curry.author: John K.
chicken katsu curry.review:
We've finally found a decent Japanese restaurant in S.F. outside the Japantown and Downtown areas. My wife, son and I lived in Japan longer than the U.S., and we're hard to please. We've gotten used to the typical beef teriyaki and tempura combo bento, the odd, only-in-America rolls, etc., that you find in California, but the flavor/seasoning is not always right, or the price is too high for standard fare, etc.
Not at Fuji. The chicken katsu curry I had was cooked right, the coating coming off a bit but not too much in the sauce, the vegetables in the curry in the right proportion, and fukujin-zuke! I never expected it would be so hard to find properly made and served Japanese curry in Northern California, but it is hard to find--look no longer, it's made right at Fuji.
The Finding Nemo was the sort of roll we'd seldom see in Japan, but that's OK--it was made well and tasted great. It was similar to the Rainbow Roll we get at Sushi to Dai For in San Rafael, but with spicy maguro in the middle.
My wife and son also greatly enjoyed their combo bentos. They are at least as hard to please as me, but the consensus was five stars!

excerpts: I ordered the seafood ramen with a salmon skin handroll.
The handroll was not too bad, but the seafood ramen was not very good because most everything starting tasting like the shoyu broth that the ramen was in.
Also, it seemed like they just threw a bunch of seafood in it, hoping it would taste good
seafood ramen.author: Lawrence E.
seafood ramen.review:
Overpriced, overrated food.  That pretty much sums up my experience here at Fuji in the West Portal area.

I went by myself had the noodle special, which they charged me an extra $2 because it's considered dinner time on a Sunday even though I came during lunch time.  I ordered the seafood ramen with a salmon skin handroll.  The handroll was not too bad, but the seafood ramen was not very good because most everything starting tasting like the shoyu broth that the ramen was in.  Also, it seemed like they just threw a bunch of seafood in it, hoping it would taste good and then the ramen noodles were overcooked that they were basically really soft with no chewiness texture to it.

After I finished that, I noticed the sign that says minimum charge on credit card is $15....I decided to be adventurous and try the toro (marbled tuna) nigiri and the sake (salmon) nigiri.  It was actually my first time ever having toro and after seeing it on cooking shows and whatnot, I was not thoroughly impressed and it cost me $19.50.  The sake was the priciest individual two piece nigiri order I have ever ordered at $5.50.  The taste of it was passable, although I think the slice of the salmon should have been a little thinner, but I guess it was getting my "money's" worth.

Also, the service wasn't that great as there was one struggling waitress trying to managed basically the whole restaurant.  At one point, she cleared away my ramen stuff with my chopsticks after I finished it, and when she gave me my nigiri orders, I basically had to go get the chopsticks myself because she wasn't very conscious of taking my chopsticks away originally.

After tax, tip, and everything, I basically spent $45 on LUNCH.  Now it is partially my fault for being adventurous to try the toro nigiri, but considering everything else, I think this is not my cup of tea.

excerpts: We had the beef sukiyaki and the una tem roll (shrimp tempura, unagi, avocado) and the bagel roll (philly cheese and salmon).
All of the food was very tasty and beautifully presented.
The server was super nice and the owner came over to make sure our dinner was nice.
The restaurant is clean and very warm.
We had all this and a tall kirin for $54.
beef sukiyaki.author: Brian L.
beef sukiyaki.review: We had the beef sukiyaki and the una tem roll (shrimp tempura, unagi, avocado) and the bagel roll (philly cheese and salmon).  All of the food was very tasty and beautifully presented.  The server was super nice and the owner came over to make sure our dinner was nice.  The restaurant is clean and very warm.  We had all this and a tall kirin for $54.

excerpts: ordered chicken sukiyaki, a variety of rolls (there were many to choose from!) , asashi tofu, and baked hamachi dished.
we enjoyed them all.
prices were reasonable.
we'd definitely return and arrive no later than 630p on a friday night especially we need to park in west portal!
chicken sukiyaki.author: FoodJunkie S.
chicken sukiyaki.review: arrived at 615 on a friday night and it was packed!  food was delicious and of good quality.  ordered chicken sukiyaki, a variety of rolls (there were many to choose from!) , asashi tofu, and baked hamachi dished.  we enjoyed them all.  prices were reasonable.  we'd definitely return and arrive no later than 630p on a friday night especially we need to park in west portal!

excerpts: We decided to order the seafood yosenabe and one of their special sushi rolls.
seafood yosenabe.author: Melissa L.
seafood yosenabe.review:
I first went to Fuji's years ago and thought it was okay.  The portions were generous but the food was standard Japanese fare.  

For a recent family dinner we decided to give Fuji another try.  We were quickly greater upon our entrance and seated immediately.  The menu contains many of the greatest hits of Japanese food - donburi, sushi, sashimi, noodles, teriyaki, tempura, bento boxes, etc.  We decided to order the seafood yosenabe and one of their special sushi rolls.  

The yosenabe was full of seafood - mussels, clams, imitation crab, shrimp and salmon, along with vegetables and clear noodles.   The dish was flavorful and and hot, with the seafood cooked perfectly.   I had one issue with this dish and it was that the broth left me really thirsty, even though I did not find the dish salty.

The sushi roll was as expected and was quite large, so expect to share these.

Our meals came with a green salad.

Patrons seemed to be locals from the neighborhood.  On a weekend evening the restaurant was mostly full.  We were walk-ins.  Parking was plentiful nearby.  Service was good, with our waiter checking in on us, refilling our beverages and possessing a great attitude.

Fuji is a nice option for dining in West Portal but is similar to so many other Japanese restaurants in the area.

excerpts: The green tea cheesecake is not so good, but everything else I tried is really fresh and yummy
green tea cheesecake.author: Emilia Z.
green tea cheesecake.review: It is a really nice place. GREAT sushi and teriyaki combos. The green tea cheesecake is not so good, but everything else I tried is really fresh and yummy

excerpts: The unagi roll and katsudon are some of the best I've ever tasted, and I love to wash it down with some imported Ginger ale.
Yum!!!
Unfortunately the service keeps me from giving this place five stars.
I am a very patient person, but I often feel I have to wait for an eternity just to get a glass of water.
The ambience feels very nice, food is delicious, service understaffed.
ginger ale.author: Christian C.
ginger ale.review: Absolutely supurb sushi!! If I could afford it I would eat here everyday. The unagi roll and katsudon are some of the best I've ever tasted, and I love to wash it down with some imported Ginger ale. Yum!!! Unfortunately the service keeps me from giving this place five stars. I am a very patient person, but I often feel I have to wait for an eternity just to get a glass of water. The ambience feels very nice, food is delicious, service understaffed.

excerpts: I had the specials - bluefin tuna nigiri and toro nigiri.
Neither were worth the price tag.
The toro was 20 dollars for two pieces.
I would happily pay anything for amazing toro (ie- ebisu in the sunset)..
But this left me with the feeling that I'd been jipped.
I'm sure their rolls are great but because the fish isn't the highest quality I wouldn't get the pricy specials.
bluefin tuna.author: Jessie L.
bluefin tuna.review: Ehhh. I had the specials - bluefin tuna nigiri and toro nigiri. Neither were worth the price tag. The toro was 20 dollars for two pieces. I would happily pay anything for amazing toro (ie- ebisu in the sunset).. But this left me with the feeling that I'd been jipped. I'm sure their rolls are great but because the fish isn't the highest quality I wouldn't get the pricy specials.

excerpts: This restaurant's food and service overall are pretty good, but I find it appalling that they serve bluefin tuna, which is an endangered species.
There are other species of tuna that are significantly less overfished, and there is no need to hunt the remaining bluefins into extinction.
As consumers we need to pressure restaurants like this to do the right thing and serve only sustainable seafood.
I will avoid Fuji as long as they serve bluefin tuna.
bluefin tuna.author: Jeff P.
bluefin tuna.review: This restaurant's food and service overall are pretty good, but I find it appalling that they serve bluefin tuna, which is an endangered species. There are other species of tuna that are significantly less overfished, and there is no need to hunt the remaining bluefins into extinction. As consumers we need to pressure restaurants like this to do the right thing and serve only sustainable seafood. I will avoid Fuji as long as they serve bluefin tuna.

excerpts: i love himachi and shiro maguro
and it's always good here.
shiro maguro.author: Bobbie L.
shiro maguro.review:
i grew up around west portal and this place has been here longer than i can remember. in the past 20-something-plus years, i think its changed hands a couple of times... but it has still remained one of our go-to neighborhood places to eat.

so i'm not saying this is the best japanese place in SF.... but in the west portal/sunset/parkside area... i would consider this place one of the better ones.

there's plenty of crazy and fancy rolls... some korean inspired dishes (korean style chirashi or jampong/spicy ramen)... but some solid japanese food and sushi. the fish is always fresh... i love himachi and shiro maguro and it's always good here. i'm a big noodle soupy type of person... and their udon is good too. 

lunch is a great deal... they have ramen noodle specials for $10.50 that come with a big bowl of noodles and a hand roll. bento boxes are HUGE... and the donburis are as well. katsu don is pretty yummy! 

the one dish i have a prob with here though is the sukiyaki! not that its bad... but they use button mushrooms instead of shiitake. completely makes it taste different.... but not bad...but not as it should be.

and i don't know why but i completely enjoy the little side salads here... comes with sunflower seeds. sweet and crunchy! :)

excerpts: When we left, there was still shiro maguro sashimi left on my plate, and not because I was full.
This experience (shiro maguro sashimi dinner, maguro sashimi, one roll for her(second was canceled) set me back $50.)
This experience (shiro maguro sashimi dinner, maguro sashimi, one roll for her(second was canceled) set me back $50.)
shiro maguro.author: John K.
shiro maguro.review:
Hmm lessee...what was the phrase from the girlfriend again?  Oh yes...

"That place was so disgusting I wouldn't feed it to our dog!  Who puts mustard on sushi?"

She ordered two rolls, I've been on a shashimi kick so I ordered that.  I'm 75% done with my very mediocre fish (had to ask myself "OK what day is it...should they have gotten a fresh delivery recently or are they coming off a weekend? Nope, they really should have fish fresher than what I get at the j-town supermarket") and she's still sitting there looking at her tea.  Finally I grumble at the wait staff, they wander off to look at what they had written on the bill - did you completely forget the order you took already?  There were 4 other tables left, the bar was mostly quiet.  I know, this is what I get for sitting at a table and not at the bar.

I too used to come to this place a few years ago(call it 2000 or so) and it was much better then.  I think it's turned into a place funded by the geriatrics who wander down out of St. Francis Wood, not knowing any better.

When we left, there was still shiro maguro sashimi left on my plate, and not because I was full.  This experience (shiro maguro sashimi dinner, maguro sashimi, one roll for her(second was canceled) set me back $50.)  I guess I helped fund their existence a little, too.

They get two stars only because I love raw fish, and I didn't get sick.  

Oh and PS, the dog did eat the roll.

excerpts: Great Uni & Ikura!
The quality of fish is amazing and the service was friendly.
Wish they didn't play top hits but that's my only complaint.
ikura.author: Candece S.
ikura.review: This restaurant deserves much higher reviews! The Poke appetizer & grilled squid is amazing.Great Uni & Ikura! The quality of fish is amazing and the service was friendly. Wish they didn't play top hits but that's my only complaint.

excerpts: I also ordered Uni nigiri, which was topped with several Ikura.
I'm not a big fan of Ikura, since it's so salty, but it brought out a light "sea" like taste of the buttery uni.
It was so good
ikura.author: Lily Y.
ikura.review:
Out with the bestie making xmas gifts can definitely work up an appetite!  Both craving for some sushi, we decided to stop here based on Peter L.'s suggestion.  Even tho craving, I'm not a big fan of sushi dining on a Monday.  It makes me question their quality... cuz everyone knows the best & the fresh stuff arrives on Thursday, just before the weekend, but don't under estimate this resto.  Thanks to Peteo's suggestion, he's got this one spot on!

FOOD & TASTE:
Ordered the Hand Roll Sampler, which comes with 3 rolls your choice of fish.  I went for Hamachi, Salmon, & Salmon Skin.  The Hamachi was super fresh, large pieces of fish, rolled with avocado... creamy & delicious!  The Salmon was lean, (I usually like mine on the fattier side) was also rolled with avocado, very fresh, went well with the seasoned sushi rice.  

I also ordered Uni nigiri, which was topped with several Ikura.  I'm not a big fan of Ikura, since it's so salty, but it brought out a light "sea" like taste of the buttery uni.  It was so good I almost got another, but at $10.50 an order, I decided to pass. 

Also tried a few other items on the menu... Double Albacore roll, Sushi Sampler, Amaebi, all of which were very tasty!  Mos definitely got my fill of sushi craving.  :-9

CONVENIENCE: **** [Located in West Portal area, on a corner block closer to the Sloat Blvd. side. Street parking or metered spot.  Easy parking on a Monday.]
AMBIANCE: *** [Nothing fancy, just your average resto. Was informed of their upstairs, which is good for groups. Also, first impression reminds me of Korean spot, based menu design.. turns out to be Korean run.]
SERVICE: **** [Nice & friendly, though nothing stellar.]
PRICE: $$  [Be prepared to spend $30 & up per person. It's sushi.]
OVERALL: **** [4-stars... for serving fresh sushi on a Monday with good quality uni.]

Good locals' joint. 
Nuff said.

[#61 of 100 YELP CHALLENGE 2013]

excerpts: Ikura - good and fresh.
ikura.author: Mi M.
ikura.review:
I feel bad writing a two-star review as my non-fish-eating Boo brought me here as a treat. Of course, he had the chicken teriyaki bento box and offloaded the salmon and tuna sashimi and the shrimp tempura on me. 

I ordered my usual litmus test sushi food as follows:

Agedashi tofu - mediocre. Over-cooked and lying in a puddle of juice - no bonito, no daikon, a little red ginger. Chipped dish. Needed a spoon too. Fail.

Ikura - good and fresh. Win.

Amaebi - didn't seem too fresh, and they tried to disguise the fact with some tobiko on to. Fried heads were overcooked. Fail.

Sea trout - lovely. Win. (It was the special, so it should have been fresh!)

Natto - Win just because they had it. It was pretty good. 

The salmon and tuna sashimi was okay. Not the freshest I've had, but it was okay. The shrimp tempura was good. 

The service was friendly but a little slow - good thing we weren't in a hurry or anything - but it took them a good 10 minutes to take our order and another 5 minutes to bring drinks. I don't mind slow service if I have a drink in front of me - it was Friday night after all!

I peeked at the bill and it seemed kind of high for what we had.

excerpts: Had uni nigiri, both with and without shiso, aji, and ikura.
I will be coming here again to try their fish listed on their "Daily Catch" board next to the sushi bar.
ikura.author: James M.
ikura.review: Their fish is really fresh. Had uni nigiri, both with and without shiso, aji, and ikura. I will be coming here again to try their fish listed on their "Daily Catch" board next to the sushi bar.

excerpts: The double albacore roll...ikura with quail egg...spicy tuna roll, hamachi, tuna, salmon...
all exceptional.
Fuji is really great.
They even put toasted rice in my tea when I requested it.
It takes the edge off.
I love this place.
Thanks for reintroducing me to Fuji Miss Michelle.
Muah!
ikura.author: Sherie R.
ikura.review:
We tried this place on a recommendation from a friend. I was disappointed. The only good item we had was the dinosaur foot. I'm sticking with Sushi Bistro- it's waaaay better. Maybe I should keep that to myself though because it's been pretty packed there lately.
*************************************************************************
Update: 7/16/2008. Had the dinosaur foot...LOVED it. The double albacore roll...ikura with quail egg...spicy tuna roll, hamachi, tuna, salmon...all exceptional. Fuji is really great. They even put toasted rice in my tea when I requested it. It takes the edge off. I love this place. Thanks for reintroducing me to Fuji Miss Michelle. Muah!

excerpts:
Liger - Shrimp tempura, salmon, shrimp, avocado, and honey mustard/mayo
Finding Nemo - Salmon and avocado over spicy tuna
Omega 3 - Tuna, Salmon, Escolar, with ponzu sauce
and of course, the Dinosaur Foot!!
escolar.author: Juliane N.
escolar.review:
Love, love, LOVEE Fuji's in West Portal! Very welcoming and friendly from the moment you step in the door until you leave. Everyone that works here is very nice and attentive to your needs. And best yet, very fresh fish!

My favorite thing to order at Fuji's, and it's a must order, would be the Dinosaur Foot! It is prepared with spicy tuna red onion, tobiko, eel sauce, honey mayo all on top of a deep fried mint leaf. Trust me, you'll love!

We also enjoy their Beef Teriyaki. Unlike some other Japanese restaurants who over cooked their beef way too much, Fuji's serves some of the best beef teriyaki I've tried. It's very tender and juicy. You can choose how you want it cooked. Others don't even give you the option of letting them know how you like your meat. Their chicken teriyaki is also a good option to go for if you're not a beef kinda person. 

Sushi rolls I love to order from here are as follow.
Liger - Shrimp tempura, salmon, shrimp, avocado, and honey mustard/mayo
Finding Nemo - Salmon and avocado over spicy tuna
Omega 3 - Tuna, Salmon, Escolar, with ponzu sauce
and of course, the Dinosaur Foot!! 

Their bento options are also very affordable and they definitely do not skimp on their portions. Their sashimi in the bento is thick cut and super fresh!

Definitely give Fuji's a shot if you haven't yet. (Dinosaur Foot!)

excerpts: Our favorites were the anago, the bonito, and the escolar,
all bursting with flavor and wonderful mouth feel.
escolar.author: Mason W.
escolar.review:
It had been a couple years since I had been to Fuji, back when I got  good sized groups of sushi fans to eat there on a few occasions.  Earlier tonight, my wife and I waited just a few minutes for perfect seats at the center of the sushi bar, right in front of the head sushi chef.  For a Friday night, the place was understandably busy.  We could see most of the other food going to other customers were a variety of maki rolls and other entrees.  Our interest was pure and simple:  nigiri, and lots of it!

The meal was surprisingly sublime.  The fish was cool, tender, fresh, and properly seasoned as appropriate, while the rice was perfectly room temperature, with the right balance of chewiness, smoothness, and subtle vinegar flavor.  We believe we were at an advantage with our close proximity to the head sushi chef.  The time from him making the nigiri to it entering our mouths could literally be measured in seconds.

Our favorites were the anago, the bonito, and the escolar, all bursting with flavor and wonderful mouth feel.  They were so good, we doubled up on those orders.  

Also good were the hotate, the kampachi, and the toro.  Less impressive, but still good, was the saba.  The hamachi sashimi was very nice.  The sunomono was good as well - I enjoyed the fresh piece of taco (octopus) from it.

The chef did comp us a special piece of toro with a nori wrap, no rice, and some sort of light color salty sauce.  That was quite nice of him.

For comparison, my wife and I commented to each other that this nigiri meal easily beat recent similar meals at Kabuto and Nagano on Geary St., and Higuma in Redwood City.  While not cheap, it was well worth the cost.

Perhaps our experience would not have been as good if we had not sat at the sushi bar, nor focused on nigiri, but since we thoroughly enjoyed this one meal, and I've had good experiences before at Fuji, I'm assigning a 5 star rating.  Choose wisely at this place for a great meal.

excerpts: The escolar was pretty tasty, but the way they cut it made it look pretty unappetizing.
I don't think I'll be coming back here for a while.
escolar.author: Richard K.
escolar.review:
I used to "like" Fuji....When I say "like", I mean it was o.k., not great, but passable.  I'd go there when I was in the mood for suhsi, but not in the mood for driving.  My latest visit made me realize that bad sushi is alot more painful than driving any day of the week.

I didn't get sick or anything, but the sushi was unremarkable.  In fact, my toro sashimi was still frozen when served to us.  The escolar was pretty tasty, but the way they cut it made it look pretty unappetizing.   I don't think I'll be coming back here for a while.

excerpts: The escolar was pretty fishy
and I wasn't all that impressed by the hamachi, which was a little off in color.
escolar.author: Jason S.
escolar.review: The people here are very nice and welcoming.  However, the sushi is not all that great.  The escolar was pretty fishy and I wasn't all that impressed by the hamachi, which was a little off in color.

excerpts:
* 

now i wanted to try escolar (aka super white)but the FDA branch is a floor below me and they've got some info on that fish.
the chef says its an oily fish because i was staring at some of the escolar nigiri he was making.
tempting..
escolar.author: Summer R.
escolar.review:
when i used to ride muni during my ventures in and around the city during my run at sfsu many moons ago, the K line was one of the lines that i took which took me through west portal. nice little neighborhood where the dogs walk their owners and there are absolutely almost no kids around....weird..   so going to fuji was like walking down memory lane. 

small little corner restaurant with huge windows. i likes already. we chose to sit at the sushi bar and greet the chef. went thru the menu and googoo gaga over the pictures of the rolls. its all so pretty looking.  i wanted to order everything, then i see the prices.  but gosh, where else can you get a roll topped with mango (looking 4 mango) or something called a liger? super special.

being adventurous with food, i wanted to try this one roll they had.  well, i ordered 2 rolls...i dont remember the names of them (excuse to go back i guess). but one of the rolls i wanted to try was one that had "raw meat on top of a hamachi roll, with cucumber and carrots, topped sesame".  like woah.. raw meat? serious? the bf looks at me with that "yea, good luck with that one" kind of look. whatever. i already tried uni back in the day.. which isnt a favorite in my book. ill just say it's "interesting" and has an "interesting" texture. anyway, the raw meat wasnt really raw. they had seared the paper thin slices of meat and let it cook and cool while the chef prepped the roll. it's actually not a bad roll. and it's not raw at all. *whew* 

now i wanted to try escolar (aka super white)but the FDA branch is a floor below me and they've got some info on that fish.  so i pass. the chef says its an oily fish because i was staring at some of the escolar nigiri he was making. tempting..but i passed this time around.

to finish off we ordered the fried bananas with green tea ice cream. nice selection of ice creams to choose from though.. green tea, red bean, ginger, vanilla, mango, sesame.  served our dessert in a martini glass, with whipped cream and a cherry on top. mmmm sexy. 

fuji is a cool place with a great selection of special rolls.. the prices..well, its not that pretty, but the creativeness makes up for it plenty.

excerpts: I like the escolar sushi.
escolar.author: brenda b.
escolar.review: Yummy food, check.  The teriyaki chicken, katsu chicken, teriyaki salmon and sushi is tasty.  However, the space factor does put a hamper on things.  They do take reservations, but the space is pretty cramped, nonetheless.  I like the escolar sushi.

excerpts: the escolar was too cold.
yep, frigid.
i started to inhale it, was dismayed to notice the chill coming off the fish onto my teeth, and put it down to reach room temp.
escolar.author: eliza w.
escolar.review:
my friends love this place (like on a first-name basis with the sushi chefs kinda thing). me, i think it's good, and a fine place to fill up on on fish and sake and beers. (while reading, remember i'm a bit of a sushi snob. so take it all with a grain of salt...and perhaps a shot of sake).

the best thing about my most recent visit? discovering that my friend kf is as much of a sushi freak as i am. this could be an expensive discovery...  

kf wasn't impressed by the amaebi, but it seemed fine to me--no old oil flavor, nice and hot and crispy. oh and the raw bit? eh, i'm always more interested in the fried bit (is that sacrilegious?). 

the unagi was huge, tender and delicious. the sea bass had a great slightly chewy consistency and great flavor (i like the sturdier fish, so i like chewy). the hamachi was ok. not the best i've had, but not the worst. the toro (i.e. our dessert) was pretty good. not to die for, but a nice finish.

the escolar was too cold. yep, frigid. i started to inhale it, was dismayed to notice the chill coming off the fish onto my teeth, and put it down to reach room temp. at which point it was lovely--good flavor, nice texture...

the uni (my first try at uni! i'm hooked!) was good. nice oceany flavor, definitely mushy, not knowledgeable enough to know if this was super fresh, but i'll definitely learn more as soon as i can.

our friend got a couple of the rolls...i wasn't tempted by any of them. there was one that had banana--heard it was a bit sweet, and might've been better as a desert. the sake was quite nice, and the service was friendly and efficient (yeeeah to my peeps).

next time i'm out drinking in the castro with kf, i'd definitely hop on muni to get a sushi fix in west portal...

excerpts: While the service was slow to get the food but quick to get you out, I decided to get a couple of rolls and my standard tako (octopus) nigiri.
The tako was horrible!
When I bit into it and it was a generous portion-
all I tasted was water from it being frozen....
I had to chew watery octopus and could not spit it out because it would have been worst!
I went to the second piece and squeezed the tako where about a 1/4 of a cup of water came out of it.
No respectable sushi chef would have sent that out....
All the sushi places I go to - tako nigiri tells me how much I will go back or not.
You now know my answer.
tako.author: A. Marie L.
tako.review:
I've been coming here for years and the food is usually good. Everything is usually delicious.... but I was surprised with my previous visit.  While the service was slow to get the food but quick to get you out, I decided to get a couple of rolls and my standard tako (octopus) nigiri.  The tako was horrible!  When I bit into it and it was a generous portion- all I tasted was water from it being frozen.... I had to chew watery octopus and could not spit it out because it would have been worst!  I went to the second piece and squeezed the tako where about a 1/4 of a cup of water came out of it.  No respectable sushi chef would have sent that out....
All the sushi places I go to - tako nigiri tells me how much I will go back or not. You now know my answer.

excerpts: Less impressive, but still good, was the saba.
saba.author: Mason W.
saba.review:
It had been a couple years since I had been to Fuji, back when I got  good sized groups of sushi fans to eat there on a few occasions.  Earlier tonight, my wife and I waited just a few minutes for perfect seats at the center of the sushi bar, right in front of the head sushi chef.  For a Friday night, the place was understandably busy.  We could see most of the other food going to other customers were a variety of maki rolls and other entrees.  Our interest was pure and simple:  nigiri, and lots of it!

The meal was surprisingly sublime.  The fish was cool, tender, fresh, and properly seasoned as appropriate, while the rice was perfectly room temperature, with the right balance of chewiness, smoothness, and subtle vinegar flavor.  We believe we were at an advantage with our close proximity to the head sushi chef.  The time from him making the nigiri to it entering our mouths could literally be measured in seconds.

Our favorites were the anago, the bonito, and the escolar, all bursting with flavor and wonderful mouth feel.  They were so good, we doubled up on those orders.  

Also good were the hotate, the kampachi, and the toro.  Less impressive, but still good, was the saba.  The hamachi sashimi was very nice.  The sunomono was good as well - I enjoyed the fresh piece of taco (octopus) from it.

The chef did comp us a special piece of toro with a nori wrap, no rice, and some sort of light color salty sauce.  That was quite nice of him.

For comparison, my wife and I commented to each other that this nigiri meal easily beat recent similar meals at Kabuto and Nagano on Geary St., and Higuma in Redwood City.  While not cheap, it was well worth the cost.

Perhaps our experience would not have been as good if we had not sat at the sushi bar, nor focused on nigiri, but since we thoroughly enjoyed this one meal, and I've had good experiences before at Fuji, I'm assigning a 5 star rating.  Choose wisely at this place for a great meal.

excerpts: the saba donburi is pretty on point as well.
saba.author: Lucy W.
saba.review:
i don't believe that rolls are a true representation of what japanese cuisine has to offer.  japanese cuisine (to me) is supposed to be modest, simple and reflect the purity of the food item that you are about to consume (sashimi, broiled mackeral, etc.) 

however, with the explosion of westernized influences on japanese cuisine, rolls are extremely popular in the US.  and to me, if it's made right, it can be a fantastic explosion of flavors and textures that our palatte can take on at once.

i believe that of all the west portal sushi establishments, this place does it right.  on a thursday nght, all of the tables were packed.  service can be a bit slow, but i barely noticed it since i was partaking in their thursday night special of 1/2 off sake and beer (and i'm a big sucker for discounted drinks).

the liger roll came and it was extremely well presented.  the honey and wasabi mayo combo on plate is such a fabulous contrast!  the portions were filling and the fish was fresh.  the saba donburi is pretty on point as well.  they serve the mackeral on a huge white platter, and while you may think that it's odd to serve it on a huge plate, i appreciated it because it allowed the mackeral to stand on it's own and shine, rather than drown in a sea of red in the typical bento boxes.

a bit expensive for sushi, but it's a welcome and comforting change from the party-filled atmosphere at other establishments in the neighborhood.  great place to go if you've got kids or want to have a conversation with someone without yelling at the top of your lungs.  and remember, you can't drink if you damage your vocal cords!

excerpts: I had a lion king roll and unagi hand roll.
The sushi was very fresh and the rice was just the right consistency.
unagi.author: Corine C.
unagi.review:
When I first walked in, the owner greeted me and made me feel right at home. The server was quick to give us suggestions and answer any questions I had about the menu. The entire staff was very kind and accommodating. 

The ambience is very pleasant! Warm and inviting with great music. Perfect for a first date or even a family dinner. 

I had a lion king roll and unagi hand roll. The sushi was very fresh and the rice was just the right consistency. Judging by how good my meal was, I am excited to try new rolls in the future. 

Highly recommend. If you live in SF or are visiting the West Portal area, definitely stop by and try the food here. This the place to be!

excerpts: The Rock and Rolls were huge rice rolls with tiny pieces of Unagi and lots of slivers of cucumber.
unagi.author: Mahin C.
unagi.review:
We went to have sushi and as a sushi lover who has been to many many sushi restaurant in San Francisco as well as all over Bay Area, I was totally disappointed.

We ordered miso soup . It had a strange after taste of cardboard to it. Then we asked for  an order of nagiri Toro. It was a good size fish but not like other toro nigiri I had before. Toro usually has a buttery taste to it and melts in your mouth. This one had chewy fish membrane  in it and did not feel that fresh ( the two piece we found out later cost us $19.50 which was extremely overpriced). Then we ordered two rolls, a Rock and Roll and a Softshell Crab Roll. They we awful. 

The Rock and Rolls were huge rice rolls with tiny pieces of Unagi and lots of slivers of cucumber. It was impossible to bite on it  as the seaweed wrap was so hard that one could not cut it with the teeth and in addition, due to the size of the roll it was impossible to put the tasteless dry roll in your mouth as a whole. 

Then came the soft shell crab roll. It was even worse. There were tiny pieces of crab legs engulfed in super salty panko breadcrumbs and fried.  These rolls were  again mostly huge amount of tasteless rice and cucumber slivers with a dash of green on the end piece.

When the bill came and we saw how outrageously overprice this restaurant is we were even more disappointed at our choice.

Fuji is a the worse sushi restaurant I have ever been to and is a waste of money.

excerpts: It's hard to do anything too terribly out of the ordinary with California, Tuna, and Unagi Makis.
I took my friend Tassie here once....
she got some outrageously monstrous roll concocted out of a cacophony of stuff.
She's a bit more clued into the Sushi thing, and said it was a lot better than average.
Looking for a quiet place to eat and hang?
I say check it out.
If you see me sitting at the sushi bar relishing my solitude while lost in introspective thought, don't be afraid to say hi.
But if you see me at Portals Tavern an hour later, mention you saw this review and I'll buy you a beer!
unagi.author: Mike W.
unagi.review:
(Sung to the tune of the theme song to "Cheers")

"Sometimes you wanna go,
      wheeeere nobody knows your naaaaame...
 But they're still glad
      that ya caaaame....
 You want be away from your hood,
      where everyone looks the saaaaame...
 You want to go where nobody knows your naaaaame..."
 (Closing bars....)
 

Ever feel that way?  I do. Dang, sometimes I feel like getting out of my neighborhood and  heading to a nearby spot where NOBODY will know me.  Eat alone. Drink alone. Shut off the cell phone, eliminating any possibility of running into old friends, thereby ensuring that anybody I meet will be someone out of the ordinary.

West Portal is my hood of choice when I'm in this type of funk.  And when I'm in the mood for something to eat, Fuji fits the bill just perfectly.  The 48 Quintara will drop you off 200 yards from the front door, and the L-Taraval will do the same if you get off right when you come out of the tunnel.  Ditto the K and M.

Typical of Japanese places, there's a sushi bar where you can sit by yourself without taking a up a whole table.  Service is prompt, polite, and not terribly verbose.  If you order a beer, they'll always ask you whether you want a big or a small one.  The big one is a bit much for dinner. Unless you plan to sit around for awhile, get the small one (12 oz).  Come the end of dinner, I'll catch the eye of the waitress and make a big "Check" sign in the air.  She'll have it to me in minutes....and it doesn't take long for them to dope out change either.  As an added bonus, all the patrons are generally middle-aged to retired and for the most part pretty reserved. Boisterous, well dressed youngsters off to glamorous events are almost unheard of here.
