excerpts: I ordered the Korean-style chirashi because I wanted to see what it would look like.
It's little cubes of (leftover?)
chirashi.author: Jacquee P.
chirashi.review:
We ordered a bunch of stuff that was okay. I ordered the Korean-style chirashi because I wanted to see what it would look like. It's little cubes of (leftover?) sashimi atop a HUGE bed of shredded green leaf and spring mix lettuces drizzled with sesame oil. There was a little mound of rice under the lettuce. You're supposed to mix it up like bibimbop with hot sauce but there is SO MUCH lettuce that it's too messy to do the mix. 

The raw kumamoto oysters were amazing! They come out pre-flavored with a dot of sauce. Add a little lemon and OMG it was perfect.

excerpts: One of my favorite dishes, by the way, is the Korean chirashi.
Worth trying if you're looking for Korean flavors in Korean-food-challenged West Portal!
chirashi.author: Marc T.
chirashi.review:
We've been going to Fuji, a good, solid sushi joint in West Portal, for many years. While not the best in the city, they have good range, fresh fish, inventive rolls and excellent, friendly service. I can't recall having a disappointing meal and have occasionally had very good ones.

They're larger than they look, having a room tucked away upstairs where they can seat larger groups, and they take reservations. So they're a pretty good place for a large-ish dinner.

One of my favorite dishes, by the way, is the Korean chirashi. Worth trying if you're looking for Korean flavors in Korean-food-challenged West Portal!

excerpts: some korean inspired dishes (korean style chirashi or jampong/spicy ramen)... but some solid japanese food and sushi.
the fish is always fresh...
chirashi.author: Bobbie L.
chirashi.review:
i grew up around west portal and this place has been here longer than i can remember. in the past 20-something-plus years, i think its changed hands a couple of times... but it has still remained one of our go-to neighborhood places to eat.

so i'm not saying this is the best japanese place in SF.... but in the west portal/sunset/parkside area... i would consider this place one of the better ones.

there's plenty of crazy and fancy rolls... some korean inspired dishes (korean style chirashi or jampong/spicy ramen)... but some solid japanese food and sushi. the fish is always fresh... i love himachi and shiro maguro and it's always good here. i'm a big noodle soupy type of person... and their udon is good too. 

lunch is a great deal... they have ramen noodle specials for $10.50 that come with a big bowl of noodles and a hand roll. bento boxes are HUGE... and the donburis are as well. katsu don is pretty yummy! 

the one dish i have a prob with here though is the sukiyaki! not that its bad... but they use button mushrooms instead of shiitake. completely makes it taste different.... but not bad...but not as it should be.

and i don't know why but i completely enjoy the little side salads here... comes with sunflower seeds. sweet and crunchy! :)

excerpts: I ordered the sashimi combo, and she ordered the chirashi.
That way we can have a comparison between the two since those are items I usually like to order.
The sashimi set had 12 pieces consisting of three each of tuna, salmon, and yellowtail.
It was pretty standard.
The fish was quite fresh and delicious.
Her chirashi made me envious though because it was highlighted by a large shrimp with the head still there.
It looked like a large amaebi (the sweet shrimp), one of my favorite at some places.
The rest of the chirashi was nicely presented also.
I will definitely order the chirashi next time I go there, and I plan to because the quality seemed quite good.
chirashi.author: H K.
chirashi.review: I came here for dinner this past Sunday night with a friend.  I ordered the sashimi combo, and she ordered the chirashi.  That way we can have a comparison between the two since those are items I usually like to order.  The sashimi set had 12 pieces consisting of three each of tuna, salmon, and yellowtail.  It was pretty standard.  The fish was quite fresh and delicious.  Her chirashi made me envious though because it was highlighted by a large shrimp with the head still there.  It looked like a large amaebi (the sweet shrimp), one of my favorite at some places.  The rest of the chirashi was nicely presented also.  I will definitely order the chirashi next time I go there, and I plan to because the quality seemed quite good.

excerpts: - I tried the chirashi don, a selection of sashimi spread on a bed of sushi rice.
The fish was nice and fresh, and the portions were ample.
Not exactly the most adventurous, however, with salmon, yellowtail, tuna, octopus, egg, and mackeral making up the sashimi.
There was also a nice, large spotted prawn joining the mix, which made for a nice presentation.

The sushi rice was also well cooked. 
-
Also tried the crunchy roll, which was spicy tuna covered in tempura crumbs and eel sauce with some more tuna on top.
The eel sauce really masks the flavor of anything else in this roll, so we couldn't really taste much of the tuna or spicy tuna.
Tempura
udon -
The broth was fairly light and the noodles were not too chewy.
Tempura was ok, as the shrimp tempura seemed a little overcooked and the tempura batter was somewhat dense.
They give a pretty good amount of it, though.
The udon also has cooked carrots in it.
$21 for the chirashi don, $4-5 for standard nigiri, $10-15 for big rolls, $14 for tempura udon (that's pricey).
Open until 10:30, so if I'm craving sushi, I'll definitely consider coming back to this place.
chirashi.author: Saunders C.
chirashi.review:
Boom. Review #200 for Fuji.

I really like little japanese restaurants like this. One of those places that sits in a sleepy little strip;  you might not notice it unless you were walking right by. But when you do venture through the door, you're surprised to find most seats filled with people happily eating their nigiri and slurping away at the udon. It's popular enough that they have their regulars who sit at the sushi bar on any given night talking to the sushi chefs. The place is very welcoming and spacious. The service was really friendly and attentive, they checked on us consistently and cleared the dishes right away. 

The menu offers a varied selection, while the fresh fish of the day are posted on the wall. They have a lot of different rolls, but one that caught my eye was the Banana Split. I love my bananas and all, but in a sushi roll? 

- I tried the chirashi don, a selection of sashimi spread on a bed of sushi rice. The fish was nice and fresh, and the portions were ample. Not exactly the most adventurous, however, with salmon, yellowtail, tuna, octopus, egg, and mackeral making up the sashimi. There was also a nice, large spotted prawn joining the mix, which made for a nice presentation. The sushi rice was also well cooked. 
- Also tried the crunchy roll, which was spicy tuna covered in tempura crumbs and eel sauce with some more tuna on top. The eel sauce really masks the flavor of anything else in this roll, so we couldn't really taste much of the tuna or spicy tuna. 
- Tempura udon - The broth was fairly light and the noodles were not too chewy. Tempura was ok, as the shrimp tempura seemed a little overcooked and the tempura batter was somewhat dense. They give a pretty good amount of it, though. The udon also has cooked carrots in it. I've heard that's a Korean influence, but I'm not sure. 

Pricewise, I'd say it's slightly above what you would expect to pay at a casual sushi restaurant. $21 for the chirashi don, $4-5 for standard nigiri, $10-15 for big rolls, $14 for tempura udon (that's pricey). Open until 10:30, so if I'm craving sushi, I'll definitely consider coming back to this place.

excerpts: Luckily, I have recently been there for dinner many times and their chirashi sushi (sashimi sushi served arranged over sushi rice) has not been problematic at all.
chirashi.author: Diana Y.
chirashi.review:
If I had written this review a year ago, I would have given it five stars without any hesitation. I have frequented this restaurant since it first opened years ago, almost weekly for lunch. Unfortunately, the chef that used to run the place left a few months ago, and an unfortunate but subsequent downgrading of their food has happened.

It may be that I am a very picky person, or it may be that Fuji used to be an excellent, excellent place which raised my standards, but there was a period of time when their nigiri did not taste fresh, which is very distasteful to me, especially when it comes to raw fish. I could not finish my meal, and I almost decided to never go back. Only its lasting legacy from the past brought me back again.

Luckily, I have recently been there for dinner many times and their chirashi sushi (sashimi sushi served arranged over sushi rice) has not been problematic at all. So it appears that whatever issue it was with their raw fish has been resolved.

I also really like their salad dressing, which is not the cream kind that is often served in sushi restaurants, but rather a light, house-made vinegarette. 

Service has always been superb, and, while dinner can be expensive, the restaurant's lunch specials are very affordable, and quite moderately priced. The place is also well-kept and neat.

My only current complaint is that Fuji used to serve the best beef teriyaki in town. It was not over-cooked, or too tough. Since the change of chefs, I have been hard-pressed to find something comparable. 

Although Fuji has lost its flare that made it exceptional for me, I would still go there just because it is still an average to good sushi restaurant with good service and tasteful food in general. However, if I ever figure out where that chef went, I will take all my business there.

excerpts: Especially the Korean Chirashi!
chirashi.author: H To The W.
chirashi.review:
As the cute little Leprechaun on the Food Network (30 Minute Meals) would say for the food here..and I quote "Yumm..OH".  

The food here is fantabulous.. Especially the Korean Chirashi!! It's a big bowl of steaming hot sushi rice with fresh sashimi, apple slices, green onions, and watercress to garnish. It also comes with a spicy red sauce so you can mix it all together (Think Bi Bim Bop). Remember to ask for minced garlic and jalapenos on the side. They won't bring it to you unless you ask for it! I know the ingredients sounds odd and you might think that the added jalapenos in addition to the spicy sauce would burn your booty-hole.. But it is well worth the sensation! (Ya know, if it does burn)

But you're taking it from a girl who packs a bottle of hot sauce in her purse, everywhere she goes.. 
Now what's in the flask is another story.

The torro (fatty tuna) sashimi is also one of the best I've tried.. It melts like buttah!

excerpts: I would recommend the Korean style chirashi, the  miso glazed black cod or the taro chips with tuna and avocado.
chirashi.author: Matt L.
chirashi.review: This place has some of the best non-sushi Japanese food that I have had. I would recommend the Korean style chirashi, the  miso glazed black cod or the taro chips with tuna and avocado.

excerpts: i had the chirashi and it was small and just ok.
again not as great as the place in fremont.
if i were to go back again for a third time it would be just for their cooked sushi.
chirashi.author: Helen L.
chirashi.review: fuji's sushi is pretty expensive but their cooked sushi is yummy. their sashimi on the other hand is nothing spectacular. i had the chirashi and it was small and just ok. again not as great as the place in fremont. if i were to go back again for a third time it would be just for their cooked sushi.

excerpts: This review is only for my Korean style Chirashi bowl, their service, and their price.
If you know what a Korean style chirashi bowl is, then sans perila/seasame leaf, this was legit.
If you know what a Korean style chirashi bowl is, then sans perila/seasame leaf, this was legit.
korean style chirashi.author: S Y.
korean style chirashi.review:
I had bookmarked Fuji to try for awhile now, and I'm bummed it took me so long to try it. This review is only for my Korean style Chirashi bowl, their service, and their price.

If you know what a Korean style chirashi bowl is, then sans perila/seasame leaf, this was legit.  Tons of quality sashimi, lots of veggies, and small bowl of rice. It made me miss my moms "hwe dup bap". I'd go back in a heartbeat just to get this dish.  My bf ordered California, Spider, and green dragon rolls and he said it was good. But nothing for him to say stellar, but he'd go back for sure.

Service was little slow. There were 2 sushi men making the rolls, and at least one or two back kitchen team, but one server. Granted we went close to 2pm, or there was a waitress shortage, service could've been better.  The waitress was sweet, kind, fast. Still, no way for her to cover the entire restaurant.

Price was reasonable. It's not a deal of the century, but it was sf price tag.

I am not sure of all of low reviews, I didn't read it, I don't think it's going to change my opinion much about now our regular spot.

excerpts:
Favorite items were:
Korean style Chirashi: nom nom nom!
Korean style basically means the fish is chopped up smaller and it came with a ton of lettuce.
I liked this, as it was sort of a combo sashimi salad/chirashi, but my BF did not like that the fish was cut up into small pieces.
Pass on the spicy sauce - use Wasabi!
Fried baby octopus appetizer
: the baby octopus are a little salty, but great flavor!

Came with salad to balance out the oilines of the octopus

hamachi on the outside!

korean style chirashi.author: Michelle L.
korean style chirashi.review:
Delicious Japanese restaurant, but a little pricier, and prepare to wait for your food!

Favorite items were:
Korean style Chirashi: nom nom nom! Korean style basically means the fish is chopped up smaller and it came with a ton of lettuce. I liked this, as it was sort of a combo sashimi salad/chirashi, but my BF did not like that the fish was cut up into small pieces. Pass on the spicy sauce - use Wasabi!
Fried baby octopus appetizer: the baby octopus are a little salty, but great flavor! Came with salad to balance out the oilines of the octopus
Double hamachi roll - hamachi on the inside... hamachi on the outside! No seaweed in this roll, which made it easier to eat. Creamy avocado and sweet sauce was super flavorful as well

The OK:
Finding nemo roll - spicy tuna no the inside, salmon and avocado on the outside. decent, but not my favorite!!

Again - it takes them a while to serve you here. They seemed to have a TON of togo orders, with only 2 waitresses and 2 sushi chefs. It wasn't too crowded... but it seemed that every aspect of service dragged on.

Come here if you don't mind the wait!!

excerpts: some korean inspired dishes (korean style chirashi or jampong/spicy ramen)... but some solid japanese food and sushi.
the fish is always fresh...
korean style chirashi.author: Bobbie L.
korean style chirashi.review:
i grew up around west portal and this place has been here longer than i can remember. in the past 20-something-plus years, i think its changed hands a couple of times... but it has still remained one of our go-to neighborhood places to eat.

so i'm not saying this is the best japanese place in SF.... but in the west portal/sunset/parkside area... i would consider this place one of the better ones.

there's plenty of crazy and fancy rolls... some korean inspired dishes (korean style chirashi or jampong/spicy ramen)... but some solid japanese food and sushi. the fish is always fresh... i love himachi and shiro maguro and it's always good here. i'm a big noodle soupy type of person... and their udon is good too. 

lunch is a great deal... they have ramen noodle specials for $10.50 that come with a big bowl of noodles and a hand roll. bento boxes are HUGE... and the donburis are as well. katsu don is pretty yummy! 

the one dish i have a prob with here though is the sukiyaki! not that its bad... but they use button mushrooms instead of shiitake. completely makes it taste different.... but not bad...but not as it should be.

and i don't know why but i completely enjoy the little side salads here... comes with sunflower seeds. sweet and crunchy! :)

excerpts: I would recommend the Korean style chirashi, the  miso glazed black cod or the taro chips with tuna and avocado.

korean style chirashi.review: This place has some of the best non-sushi Japanese food that I have had. I would recommend the Korean style chirashi, the  miso glazed black cod or the taro chips with tuna and avocado.

excerpts: The menu contains many of the greatest hits of Japanese food - donburi, sushi, sashimi, noodles, teriyaki, tempura, bento boxes, etc.
donburi.author: Melissa L.
donburi.review:
I first went to Fuji's years ago and thought it was okay.  The portions were generous but the food was standard Japanese fare.  

For a recent family dinner we decided to give Fuji another try.  We were quickly greater upon our entrance and seated immediately.  The menu contains many of the greatest hits of Japanese food - donburi, sushi, sashimi, noodles, teriyaki, tempura, bento boxes, etc.  We decided to order the seafood yosenabe and one of their special sushi rolls.  

The yosenabe was full of seafood - mussels, clams, imitation crab, shrimp and salmon, along with vegetables and clear noodles.   The dish was flavorful and and hot, with the seafood cooked perfectly.   I had one issue with this dish and it was that the broth left me really thirsty, even though I did not find the dish salty.

The sushi roll was as expected and was quite large, so expect to share these.

Our meals came with a green salad.

Patrons seemed to be locals from the neighborhood.  On a weekend evening the restaurant was mostly full.  We were walk-ins.  Parking was plentiful nearby.  Service was good, with our waiter checking in on us, refilling our beverages and possessing a great attitude.

Fuji is a nice option for dining in West Portal but is similar to so many other Japanese restaurants in the area.

excerpts: ,  steak teriyaki was bland and sake donburi unfilling.
Requested ice water that had about 2 dots of ice and my water was warm.
Ugh!
Tried dessert and waited an additional 15 - 20min.
Too pricey for what we dealt with.
No need to return.
donburi.author: REBECCA S.
donburi.review: I used to frequent this restaurant in my 20s.  Escaping the heat of the East Bay I decided to bring some family in.  The service was mediocre but got better as they tried to make room for incoming customers.   The spicy ramen was flavorful and full of seafood,  steak teriyaki was bland and sake donburi unfilling. Requested ice water that had about 2 dots of ice and my water was warm.  Ugh!  Tried dessert and waited an additional 15 - 20min.  Too pricey for what we dealt with. No need to return.

excerpts: My sister got the tempura donburi, I got the dinner bento box two and my mom got the bento box three.
All the dinner menu items come with miso soup and salad (PS salad dressing is yummy); bento boxes get a side of rice.
We also decided to order a "Finding Nemo" roll (spicy tuna, salmon, avocado, roe) that came out way later while we were in the middle-almost end of our main dishes...
donburi.author: Kathleen S.
donburi.review:
For the sake of how long I've been living in this area, I'm really surprised I never decided to walk into this restaurant until a few days ago. It isn't very visually appealing and can be easily missed on the corner, but once you're in it's actually pretty cozy like you're at a local cafe.

On a weekend this place was just the right amount of crowded, meaning that my sister, mom and I didn't have to wait long for a table even though there were a few parties ahead of us and people leaving the restaurant. Now onto the food; the prices overall are a little steep, but in the end it was pretty worth it for the amount of food you get. My sister got the tempura donburi, I got the dinner bento box two and my mom got the bento box three. All the dinner menu items come with miso soup and salad (PS salad dressing is yummy); bento boxes get a side of rice. We also decided to order a "Finding Nemo" roll (spicy tuna, salmon, avocado, roe) that came out way later while we were in the middle-almost end of our main dishes... I don't know if I would order both dinner items and sushi rolls if they don't come out at the same time.

Anyways, I LOVED my bento box two; came with salmon teriyaki, a decent portion of tuna and salmon sashimi (these were FAT pieces and probably one of the places I can recommend for very fresh fish), shrimp and veggie tempura, and this side of spinach with ponzu sauce. The bento box three my mom got had two skewers of yakitori, an eggplant side, veggie tempura and california roll. Both boxes were about $17-$19 which isn't too bad for what you're getting.

Downside of my experience: they weren't on top of refilling our waters or asking if everything was okay. I would definitely come back for the sashimi , but maybe to-go this time. ALSO pay cash for 10% off your bill!

excerpts: I ordered the oyako-donburi and it resembled none I'd had before, and not in a good way.
donburi.author: jim b.
donburi.review:
I don't do many reviews any more and hesitate to write bad ones but I wouldn't go here again. There is nothing to recommend the place except they seem to keep long hours. The flavors were dull and prices were a little steep for what you got. I ordered the oyako-donburi and it resembled none I'd had before, and not in a good way. 

With so many good Japanese places in SF, I'd give Fuji a pass. Unless nothing else is open.

excerpts: We ordered the chicken and the katsu donburi and both were very basic, yet terrible.
The katsu was wet and chewy, not crispy like usual, and the chicken was pretty bland.
The rice was very mushy as well.
Nowhere near worth the high price.
Ugh.

donburi.review: Pricey, yet so disappointing. We ordered the chicken and the katsu donburi and both were very basic, yet terrible.  The katsu was wet and chewy, not crispy like usual, and the chicken was pretty bland.  The rice was very mushy as well. Nowhere near worth the high price. Ugh.

excerpts: KATSU DONBURI DEEP FRIED PORK CUTLET
donburi.author: William B.
donburi.review:
Its been a while since I have not eaten at Japanese restaurant since the very last time I ate at Kamakura.. I have decided to explore another Japanese Restauraant this time I went to go try Fuji for lunch and had myself these items which I have eaten at Fuji during the lunch time hour...


KATSU DONBURI DEEP FRIED PORK CUTLET IN KATSU SAUCE W/ EGG

CALIFORNIA ROLL W/ REAL CRAB, AVOCADO AND CUCUMBER 5 PIECES AND ALSO COMES WITH MISO SOUP 

I ALSO WANTED TO TRY ASAHI BEER IN WHICH I DID IT TASTED GREAT

AFTER ALL NOW THAT I HAVE EATEN AT FUJI FOR THE FIRST TIME THE LUNCH MEAL THAT I HAVE EATEN WASNT THAT BAD AT ALL!!!

excerpts: My sister ordered the Oyako Donburi (Chicken/Egg over rice).
The Bento was decent, but definitely nothing special at all.
California Rolls were a good size, but were prepared very sloppy.
I guess the sushi chef didn't get a good grip on the bamboo wrap, to where the rice wasn't tightly put together.
donburi.author: Cass J.
donburi.review:
Nothing special or memorable... just simple and expensive.  Upon walking into Fuji for lunch today, we were greeted by our Korean waitress Young Jin, quickly seated.  We were somewhat confused about the attitude of the restaurant as there was Mexican music playing.  But what they hey, we were hungry, and didn't want go to far for lunch.  As more folks walked in for lunch, the music quickly changed to Japanese music.  

Prices for lunch weren't insanely unreasonable, but for the quality it definitely wasn't worth it.  We ordered the Vegetable Tempura appetizer which was alright--the batter became quite soggy very fast. But we were hungry, so we didn't take long to kill the plate.  

I ordered the Bento Box of California Roll and Chicken Teriyaki.  Bento's came with miso.  My sister ordered the Oyako Donburi (Chicken/Egg over rice).  The Bento was decent, but definitely nothing special at all.   California Rolls were a good size, but were prepared very sloppy. I guess the sushi chef didn't get a good grip on the bamboo wrap, to where the rice wasn't tightly put together.  Needless to say, the rice came apart very easy.  

The Oyako Don, was lacking in flavor and very bland, Angie had to pour the remaining Tempura sauce over her rice, and even that didn't help much.  

We also ordered the Lion King Roll, which was a California Roll with cooked Salmon on top.  Eh...it was just as sloppily made with the rice falling off on certain parts.  

Overall, the food wasn't terrible, I actually really liked the California Roll and Tempura, but it definitely wasn't anything that made me say "Wow!"

$45.00 with tip...

excerpts: I order their Donburi to give a try
however I was so disappointed the egg was over cook vegetables
were not fresh!
Service was really bad, me and my boy friend have been waiting over 20 mins to took our order!

excerpts: The Donburi is just like "Grandma used to make".
Totally country style.
Comfort food at it's best.
Also had the Agadashi Tofu and it was only "meh".
Wouldn't get it again, so minus one star.
Japanese owned and operated which in my book is totally key.
Jammin' the JPop over the sound system didn't hurt either.

donburi.author: Natas N.
donburi.review:
Had the Tendon here for lunch today. It was KILLER! The Donburi is just like "Grandma used to make". Totally country style. Comfort food at it's best. Also had the Agadashi Tofu and it was only "meh". Wouldn't get it again, so minus one star. Japanese owned and operated which in my book is totally key. Jammin' the JPop over the sound system didn't hurt either. Don't frequent West Portal to often, but it seems like a pretty good spot. Parking was a breeze at lunchtime. 

Domo!

excerpts: the saba donburi is pretty on point as well.
donburi.author: Lucy W.
donburi.review:
i don't believe that rolls are a true representation of what japanese cuisine has to offer.  japanese cuisine (to me) is supposed to be modest, simple and reflect the purity of the food item that you are about to consume (sashimi, broiled mackeral, etc.) 

however, with the explosion of westernized influences on japanese cuisine, rolls are extremely popular in the US.  and to me, if it's made right, it can be a fantastic explosion of flavors and textures that our palatte can take on at once.

i believe that of all the west portal sushi establishments, this place does it right.  on a thursday nght, all of the tables were packed.  service can be a bit slow, but i barely noticed it since i was partaking in their thursday night special of 1/2 off sake and beer (and i'm a big sucker for discounted drinks).

the liger roll came and it was extremely well presented.  the honey and wasabi mayo combo on plate is such a fabulous contrast!  the portions were filling and the fish was fresh.  the saba donburi is pretty on point as well.  they serve the mackeral on a huge white platter, and while you may think that it's odd to serve it on a huge plate, i appreciated it because it allowed the mackeral to stand on it's own and shine, rather than drown in a sea of red in the typical bento boxes.

a bit expensive for sushi, but it's a welcome and comforting change from the party-filled atmosphere at other establishments in the neighborhood.  great place to go if you've got kids or want to have a conversation with someone without yelling at the top of your lungs.  and remember, you can't drink if you damage your vocal cords!

excerpts: Had the salmon teriyaki lunch special.
The mainly iceberg salad was warm with a watery dressing that had absolutely no taste.
There was water at the bottom of the bowl.
The rice was hard/dry and room temperature.
The salmon was simply bad and from the way it felt in my mouth
it seemed like it was cooked, or rather OVERcooked, way before (like even days before)
I ordered it and then it was reheated, but just ever so slightly!
The teriyaki sauce was insipid.
Be warned.
Just because the plates are 15" in diameter doesn't make the food taste any better.

The salmon was simply bad and from the way it felt in my mouth it seemed like it was cooked, or rather OVERcooked, way before (like even days before) I ordered it and then it was reheated, but just ever so slightly!  The teriyaki sauce was insipid.  Be warned.  Just because the plates are 15" in diameter doesn't make the food taste any better.
